abstract: <jats:p>Genetic variants associated with fasting glucose in <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">E</jats:styled-content>uropean ancestry populations are increasingly well understood. However, the nature of the associations between these single nucleotide polymorphisms (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content>s) and fasting glucose in other racial and ethnic groups is unclear. We sought to examine regions previously identified to be associated with fasting glucose in Caucasian genome‐wide association studies (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">GWAS</jats:styled-content>) across multiple ethnicities in the Multiethnic Study of Atherosclerosis (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">MESA</jats:styled-content>). Nondiabetic MESA participants with fasting glucose measured at the baseline exam and with <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">GWAS</jats:styled-content> genotyping were included; 2,349 Caucasians, 664 individuals of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">C</jats:styled-content>hinese descent, 1,366 <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>frican <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>mericans, and 1,171 <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">H</jats:styled-content>ispanics. Genotype data were generated from the <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>ffymetrix 6.0 array and imputation in <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">IMPUTE</jats:styled-content>. Fasting glucose was regressed on <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content> dosage data in each ethnic group adjusting for age, gender, <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">MESA</jats:styled-content> study center, and ethnic‐specific principal components. SNPs from the three gene regions with the strongest associations to fasting glucose in previous <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">C</jats:styled-content>aucasian <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">GWAS</jats:styled-content> (<jats:italic>MTNR1B</jats:italic> / <jats:italic>GCK</jats:italic> / <jats:italic>G6PC2</jats:italic>) were examined in depth. There was limited power to replicate associations in other ethnic groups due to smaller allele frequencies and limited sample size; <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content> associations may also have differed across ethnic groups due to differing linkage disequilibrium patterns with causal variants. rs10830963 in <jats:italic>MTNR1B</jats:italic> and rs4607517 in <jats:italic>GCK</jats:italic> demonstrated consistent magnitude and direction of association with fasting glucose across ethnic groups, although the associations were often not nominally significant. In conclusion, certain <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content>s in <jats:italic>MTNR1B</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>GCK</jats:italic> demonstrate consistent effects across four racial and ethnic groups, narrowing the putative region for these causal variants. Genet. Epidemiol. 36:384–391, 2012. © 2012 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.</jats:p>

reference.article-title: Variations in the G6PC2/ABCB11 genomic region are associated with fasting glucose levels
reference.author: Chen WM

reference.unstructured: GaudermanWJ MorrisonJM.2010.Quanto 1.1: a computer program for power and sample size calculations for genetic epidemiology studies.

title: Fasting Glucose <scp>GWAS</scp> Candidate Region Analysis Across Ethnic Groups in the Multiethnic Study of Atherosclerosis (<scp>MESA</scp>)
